text:

Please note that the images are not displaying correctly on the GitHub hosted webpage, despite showing on the webpage when hosted locally.
If the images and plots are not visible, screenshots of them can be found in the folder
content\01_journal\Plots

Intro To the tidyverse Challenges

Data Wrangling Challenges

title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website everytime before you want to upload changes

title: Class Notes
text:
IMPORTANT: You can delete everything in here and start fresh. You might want to start by not deleting anything above this line until you know what that stuff is doing.
This is an .qmd file. It is plain text with special features. Any time you write just like this, it will be compiled to normal text in the website. If you put a # in front of your text, it will create a top level-header.

title: Data Wrangling
text:
library(vroom)
library(tidyverse)
library(data.table)


1 Challenge Part 1:

#importing data
patent_assignee_col_types <- list(
  patent_id = col_character(),
  assignee_id = col_character()
)

patent_assignee_tbl <- vroom(
  file       = "DataWrangling/Patent_data_reduced/patent_assignee.tsv", 
  delim      = "\t", 
  col_types  = patent_assignee_col_types,
  na         = c("", "NA", "NULL")
)

assignee_col_types <- list(
  id = col_character(),
  type = col_integer(),
  organization = col_character()
)

assignee_tbl <- vroom(
  file       = "DataWrangling/Patent_data_reduced/assignee.tsv", 
  delim      = "\t", 
  col_types  = assignee_col_types,
  na         = c("", "NA", "NULL")
)

patent_col_types <- list(
  id = col_character(),
  date = col_date("%Y-%m-%d"),
  num_claims = col_double()
)

patent_tbl <- vroom(
  file       = "DataWrangling/Patent_data_reduced/patent.tsv", 
  delim      = "\t", 
  col_types  = patent_col_types,
  na         = c("", "NA", "NULL")
)

uspc_col_types <- list(
  patent_id = col_character(),
  mainclass_id = col_character(),
  sequence = col_integer()
)

uspc_tbl <- vroom(
  file       = "DataWrangling/Patent_data_reduced/uspc.tsv", 
  delim      = "\t", 
  col_types  = uspc_col_types,
  na         = c("", "NA", "NULL")
)


rm(assignee_col_types,patent_col_types,uspc_col_types,patent_assignee_col_types)


setDT(assignee_tbl)

setDT(patent_assignee_tbl)

setkey(assignee_tbl,id)
setkey(patent_assignee_tbl,assignee_id)


combined_data_tbl <- assignee_tbl[patent_assignee_tbl]

temp <-combined_data_tbl[,.N,by = organization]

setDT(temp)

setorder(temp,-N)

temp[1:5,,]



  




2 Challenge Part 2:

combined_data_tbl <- combined_data_tbl[patent_tbl, on = c(patent_id="id")]

combined_data_tbl <- na.omit(combined_data_tbl) #remove rows where organisation is NULL

temp_tbl <- combined_data_tbl[month(date)==5 & year(date)==2014 & !is.null(organization),.N, by = organization]

setorder(temp_tbl,-N)

temp_tbl[1:10,,]



  




3 Challenge Part 3:

setkey(uspc_tbl,NULL)
setkey(patent_tbl,NULL)
setkey(patent_assignee_tbl,NULL)
setDT(uspc_tbl)
combined_data_tbl <-uspc_tbl[patent_assignee_tbl,on = "patent_id"]
combined_data_tbl <- combined_data_tbl[assignee_tbl,on = c(assignee_id="id")]
setDT(combined_data_tbl)

combined_data_tbl <- na.omit(combined_data_tbl)

temp_tbl <-combined_data_tbl[,.(patents= .N),by=.(organization, mainclass_id)]  

setDT(temp_tbl)
setorder(temp_tbl,-patents)
temp_tbl<-temp_tbl[1:10,.('Occurence in top 10'=.N),by=mainclass_id] 
temp_tbl[1:5,,]

title: Tidyverse
text:
#1: Analyse sales by location with bar plot


bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl <- bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl %>%
  # Separate location into city and state
  separate(col    = location,
           into   = c("city", "state"),
           sep    = ", ")

sales_by_state_tbl <- bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl %>%
  
  #select columns
  select(total_price, state) %>%
  
  
  #group by year & summarise sales
  
  group_by(state)%>%
  summarise(sales = sum(total_price)) %>%
  
  mutate(sales_text = scales::dollar(sales, big.mark = ".", 
                                     decimal.mark = ",", 
                                     prefix = "", 
                                     suffix = " €"))
sales_by_state_tbl



  




# Step 2 - Visualize

sales_by_state_tbl %>%
  
  ggplot(aes(x=state,y=sales)) +
  
  geom_col(fill="#2DC6D6")+
  geom_label(aes(label = sales_text))+
  geom_smooth(method="lm",se=FALSE)+
  
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::dollar_format(big.mark = ".", 
                                                    decimal.mark = ",", 
                                                    prefix = "", 
                                                    suffix = " €")) +
  labs(
    title    = "Revenue by State",
    x = "", # Override defaults for x and y
    y = "Revenue"
  )+
  
   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

#> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

library(data.table)

covid_data_tbl <- read_csv("https://covid.ourworldindata.org/data/owid-covid-data.csv")

#> Delimiter: ","

#> dbl  (62): total_cases, new_cases, new_cases_smoothed, total_deaths, new_dea...

title: Links
text:
R is a free open-source programming language that can be used for statistical analysis, data-simulation, graphing, and lots of other stuff. Another free program is R-studio, that provides a nice graphic interface for R. Download R first, then download R-studio. Both can run on PCs, Macs or Linux. Students will be learning R in the stats labs using the lab manual .




Google is great, Google your problem
Stackoverflow is great, google will often take you there because someone has already asked your question, and someone else has answered, usually many people have answered your question many ways.

title: My Lab Journal
section: 1: Analyse sales by location with bar plot
text:
1: Analyse sales by location with bar plot

Manipulation
bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl <- bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl %>% # Separate location into city and state separate(col = location, into = c(“city”, “state”), sep = “,”)
library(lubridate)
sales_by_state_tbl <- bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl %>%
#select columns select(total_price, state) %>%
#group by year & summarise sales
group_by(state)%>% summarise(sales = sum(total_price)) %>%
mutate(sales_text = scales::dollar(sales, big.mark = “.”, decimal.mark = “,”, prefix = ““, suffix =” €“)) sales_by_state_tbl


Visualising
sales_by_state_tbl %>%
ggplot(aes(x=state,y=sales)) +
geom_col(fill=“#2DC6D6”)+ geom_label(aes(label = sales_text))+ geom_smooth(method=“lm”,se=FALSE)+
scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::dollar_format(big.mark = “.”, decimal.mark = “,”, prefix = ““, suffix =” €“)) + labs( title =”Revenue by State”, x = ““, # Override defaults for x and y y =”Revenue” )+
theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

title: My Lab Journal
section: 2: analyse sales by location and year(facet_wrap)
text:
2: analyse sales by location and year(facet_wrap)
### Manipulation
sales_by_year_state_tbl <- bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl %>%
select(order_date, total_price, state) %>% mutate(year = year(order_date)) %>%
group_by(year,state) %>% summarise(sales = sum(total_price)) %>% ungroup() %>%
mutate(sales_text = scales::dollar(sales,big.mark = “.”, decimal.mark = “,”, prefix = ““, suffix =” €“))
sales_by_year_state_tbl
### Visualisation
sales_by_year_state_tbl %>%
# Set up x, y, fill ggplot(aes(x = year, y = sales, fill = state)) +
# Geometries geom_col() + # Run up to here to get a stacked bar plot
geom_smooth(method = “lm”, se = FALSE) + # Adding a trendline
# Facet facet_wrap(~ state) +
# Formatting scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::dollar_format(big.mark = “.”, decimal.mark = “,”, prefix = ““, suffix =” €“)) + labs( title =”Revenue by year and State”, fill = “State” # Changes the legend name )

title: My Lab Journal
text:
Challenge 1

#1: Analyse sales by location with bar plot


bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl <- bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl %>%
  # Separate location into city and state
  separate(col    = location,
           into   = c("city", "state"),
           sep    = ", ")

sales_by_state_tbl <- bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl %>%
  
  #select columns
  select(total_price, state) %>%
  
  
  #group by year & summarise sales
  
  group_by(state)%>%
  summarise(sales = sum(total_price)) %>%
  
  mutate(sales_text = scales::dollar(sales, big.mark = ".", 
                                     decimal.mark = ",", 
                                     prefix = "", 
                                     suffix = " €"))
sales_by_state_tbl

# A tibble: 12 × 3
   state                            sales sales_text  
   <chr>                            <dbl> <chr>       
 1 Baden-Württemberg              6521090 6.521.090 € 
 2 Bavaria                        6742819 6.742.819 € 
 3 Berlin                         1128433 1.128.433 € 
 4 Bremen                        10653499 10.653.499 €
 5 Hamburg                        3874756 3.874.756 € 
 6 Hesse                          1558901 1.558.901 € 
 7 Lower Saxony                   4107115 4.107.115 € 
 8 Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania   618974 618.974 €   
 9 North Rhine-Westphalia        21200613 21.200.613 €
10 Saxony                         2230245 2.230.245 € 
11 Saxony-Anhalt                   569614 569.614 €   
12 Schleswig-Holstein             3224749 3.224.749 € 



# Step 2 - Visualize

sales_by_state_tbl %>%
  
  ggplot(aes(x=state,y=sales)) +
  
  geom_col(fill="#2DC6D6")+
  geom_label(aes(label = sales_text))+
  geom_smooth(method="lm",se=FALSE)+
  
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::dollar_format(big.mark = ".", 
                                                    decimal.mark = ",", 
                                                    prefix = "", 
                                                    suffix = " €")) +
  labs(
    title    = "Revenue by State",
    x = "", # Override defaults for x and y
    y = "Revenue"
  )+
  
   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'









#

title: My Lab Journal
text:
Challenge 2

  #Step 1: Manipulate

sales_by_year_state_tbl <- bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl %>%
  
  select(order_date, total_price, state) %>%
  mutate(year = year(order_date)) %>%
  
  group_by(year,state) %>%
  summarise(sales = sum(total_price)) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  
  mutate(sales_text = scales::dollar(sales,big.mark = ".",
                                     decimal.mark = ",",
                                     prefix = "",
                                     suffix = " €"))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'year'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

sales_by_year_state_tbl

# A tibble: 60 × 4
    year state                           sales sales_text 
   <dbl> <chr>                           <dbl> <chr>      
 1  2015 Baden-Württemberg             1031924 1.031.924 €
 2  2015 Bavaria                       1301461 1.301.461 €
 3  2015 Berlin                          95853 95.853 €   
 4  2015 Bremen                        1395912 1.395.912 €
 5  2015 Hamburg                        423090 423.090 €  
 6  2015 Hesse                          308609 308.609 €  
 7  2015 Lower Saxony                   584386 584.386 €  
 8  2015 Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania  222003 222.003 €  
 9  2015 North Rhine-Westphalia        3735092 3.735.092 €
10  2015 Saxony                         238371 238.371 €  
# ℹ 50 more rows



# Step 2: Visualise


sales_by_year_state_tbl %>%
  
  # Set up x, y, fill
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = sales, fill = state)) +
  
  # Geometries
  geom_col() + # Run up to here to get a stacked bar plot
  
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + # Adding a trendline
  
  # Facet
  facet_wrap(~ state) +
  
  # Formatting
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::dollar_format(big.mark = ".", 
                                                    decimal.mark = ",", 
                                                    prefix = "", 
                                                    suffix = " €")) +
  labs(
    title = "Revenue by year and State",
    fill = "State" # Changes the legend name
  )

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'









#

title: Tidyverse
text:
#1: Analyse sales by location with bar plot


bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl <- bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl %>%
  # Separate location into city and state

           into   = c("city", "state"),
           sep    = ", ")

  geom_label(aes(label = sales_text))+

title: Tidyverse
text:
2 Challenge 2

  #Step 1: Manipulate

sales_by_year_state_tbl <- bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl %>%
  
  select(order_date, total_price, state) %>%
  mutate(year = year(order_date)) %>%
  
  group_by(year,state) %>%
  summarise(sales = sum(total_price)) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  
  mutate(sales_text = scales::dollar(sales,big.mark = ".",
                                     decimal.mark = ",",
                                     prefix = "",
                                     suffix = " €"))

#> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'year'. You can override using the
#> `.groups` argument.

sales_by_year_state_tbl



  




# Step 2: Visualise


sales_by_year_state_tbl %>%
  
  # Set up x, y, fill
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = sales, fill = state)) +
  
  # Geometries

  # Formatting
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::dollar_format(big.mark = ".",

                                                    prefix = "", 
                                                    suffix = " €")) +
  labs(
    title = "Revenue by year and State",
    fill = "State" # Changes the legend name
  )

title: Data Visualization
text:
library(data.table)
library(tidyverse)
covid_data_tbl <- read_csv("https://covid.ourworldindata.org/data/owid-covid-data.csv")

#> Rows: 397677 Columns: 67
#> ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
#> Delimiter: ","
#> chr   (4): iso_code, continent, location, tests_units
#> dbl  (62): total_cases, new_cases, new_cases_smoothed, total_deaths, new_dea...
#> date  (1): date
#> 
#> ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
#> ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

title: Data Visualization
text:
2 Challenge 1

# Challenge 1: Plot covid cases per month per country

## plot should be line graph, each country different colour scale =25 Million
## plot should contain date, cumulative cases, country
covid_data_reduced_tbl <- covid_data_tbl %>%
                          select(location,total_cases,date,continent)%>%
                          #filter(starts_with(location, "Ger") )
                          filter(date<"2022-05-31" )%>%
                          #filter(continent=='Europe')%>%
                          #complete(total_cases_per_million) %>% 
                          mutate(across(total_cases, ~replace_na(., 0)))%>%
                          filter(location =="Germany"|location =="United Kingdom"|location =="France"|location =="Spain"|location =="United States")
                            

covid_data_reduced_tbl %>%
  
  #distinct(date,total_cases_per_million,location)
  ggplot(aes(date,total_cases,group = location, color = location)) +
    geom_line()+
    geom_smooth(span = 0.05)+
  scale_x_date(
      NULL,
      breaks = scales::breaks_width("1 months"),
      date_labels = "%b '%y"
      #scale_x_date(date_labels = "%b %y")
  )+
  
  scale_y_continuous(
    labels = scales::label_number(scale = 1e-6, 
                                  preix = "",
                                  suffix = "M")
  )+
  
  labs(
    title = "COVID-19 Confirmed Worldwide Cases",
    subtitle = "As of 01-07-2022",
    x="Month",
    y = "Cumulative Cases",
    color = "Country"
    
  )+
  theme(legend.position = 'bottom',
        legend.direction = "horizontal",
        legend.text.position = "bottom",
        legend.background = element_rect(fill = 'transparent'),
        legend.box.background = element_rect(fill='transparent'),
        plot.background = element_rect(fill="transparent",color=NA),
        strip.background = element_rect(fill = 'transparent'),
        axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)
        )

#> `geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'








plot can be found at: \content\01_journal\Plots\covid_cases_worldwide.png

title: Data Visualization
text:
3 Challenge 2

world <- map_data("world")

world_tbl <- world%>%
              select(long,lat,group,order,region)

rm("world")

covid_data_world <-covid_data_tbl %>%
                    select(location,total_deaths_per_million,date,continent)%>%
                    mutate(across(total_deaths_per_million, ~replace_na(., 0)))%>% 
                    mutate(mortality = total_deaths_per_million/1)%>%
                    filter(date =="2024-04-28") %>%
                    mutate(location = case_when(
                    location == "United Kingdom" ~ "UK",
                    location == "United States" ~ "USA",
                    location == "Democratic Republic of Congo" ~ "Democratic Republic of the Congo",
                    TRUE ~ location
                  )) %>%
                  distinct()
                   


setDT(covid_data_world)
setDT(world_tbl)

covid_data_world <- covid_data_world[world_tbl,on = c(location="region")]


ggplot(covid_data_world, aes(long, lat, group = group))+
  geom_polygon(aes(fill =mortality ), color = "lightgrey")+
  scale_fill_gradient(low="red",
                      high ="black",
                      name = "Mortality rate\n(Deaths per million)")+
  
  labs(
    title = "COVID-19 Confirmed Worldwide Deaths relative to population size",
    subtitle = "As of 28-04-2024",
    x="",
    y = "",
  )+
  theme(axis.text.x = element_blank(),
        axis.text.y = element_blank(),
        )







plot can be found at: \content\01_journal\Plots\map_covid_mortality.png

title: Data Acquisition
text:
1.1 Challenge Part 2

url_home        <- "https://www.rosebikes.de/fahrr%C3%A4der"

html_home       <- read_html(url_home)
html_home |> xml2::write_html("radon_bikes.html")


bike_categories_chr <- html_home |>
  
  html_elements(css = ".catalog-navigation__link") |>
  
  html_attr('href') |>
  
  str_c("https://www.rosebikes.de", ... =_)


bike_categories_chr

#> [1] "https://www.rosebikes.de/fahrräder/gravel"           
#> [2] "https://www.rosebikes.de/fahrräder/rennrad"          
#> [3] "https://www.rosebikes.de/fahrräder/mtb"              
#> [4] "https://www.rosebikes.de/fahrräder/urban-&-trekking" 
#> [5] "https://www.rosebikes.de/fahrräder/e-bike"           
#> [6] "https://www.rosebikes.de/fahrräder/sale"             
#> [7] "https://www.rosebikes.de/bike-finder"                
#> [8] "https://www.rosebikes.de/bikes-mit-kurzer-lieferzeit"

# Select gravel bike category
bike_category_url <- bike_categories_chr[1]

# Get the URLs for the bikes of the first category
html_bike_category  <- read_html(bike_category_url)

bike_url_chr        <- html_bike_category |>
  
  html_elements(".basic-headline__title") |>
  
  
  html_attr("href")

bike_url_chr

#>  [1] NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA
